narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This seminar afforded us an opportunity to understand how it is writers use their craft to respond to moments of crisis. We did so by considering questions of 'publicness,' audience, and voice. By reading and critically responding to a variety of texts, you learn what the architecture of public-facing work is and what tools writers employ to reach that design. Collaborations with the Yale Prison Education Initiative were eye-opening and a fantastic addition to this course. Through that opportunity and with the midterm paper assignment, this course provides you with an understanding on how to bring yourself to the page. A useful experience for cultivating shared forms of knowledge production, the final project allowed us to explore topics of our interest and to collaboratively make a zine!

- public writing 
- analysis 
- how different writers deploy different strategies to speak to their audiences

In this course we read a range of nonfiction, public-facing writers on topics including race relations, the healthcare system, and science writing. The course ended with a collective piece put together by the class to be distributed to YPEI students
I gained a greater understanding and appreciation for public writing and the thought and structure that goes into forming a compelling piece of public writing.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: Guest speakers, YPEI collaborations, class blog, & Professor Mirakhor's syllabus, insights, and voice. Prof Mirakhor enriches seminar discussion in insightful ways and *actually* reads student discussion posts! Weaknesses: n/a

strengths: The readings on the syllabus were amazing and thought-provoking; they come from a range of perspectives and genres. Professor Mirakhor is incredible, and she really pushes her students to think deeper and more critically about the material, the purposes of public writing, the relationship between writing, organizing, and activism, and what we intend to do with our Yale education/ the ethics of being a part of this institution. Although I really wished I could have experienced this class in person, the small seminar format allowed for individualized learning, and was an enriching part of my semester. The benefit of zoom was that we could engage with different guest speakers and have joint classes with Professor HoSang's Community Organizing class. In light of the pandemic, Mirakhor demonstrated a sincere care for our well-being, and was flexible and gracious. 

weaknesses: zoom fatigue of course

A strength of this course was that it allowed for in depth evaluations of the readings, and the times we got to speak with the authors were especially illuminating. A weakness might have been an overall lack of engagement with the course likely largely due to the online format and difficulty of small seminars over zoom
The readings are incredibly interesting and Professor Mirakhor does a great job of encouraging the students to try and think deeper about what author's are trying to convey and how they do so.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? comments: The length of the online small seminar was sometimes difficult. The questions and answer session with authors worked well in the online format
Professor Mirakhor did a great job of providing insightful feedback and making the course engaging in spirt of the pandemic.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: yes! this course is perfect for people who are serious about their writing reaching broad publics and are looking for practices to make that public vision real
Absolutely! Professor Mirakhor is fantastic, and you'll get to engage with deep questions about writing, activism, and organizing!

If you are interested in writing to a public audience in the future, this course might be a good choice for you. Keep in mind that this course is more focused on studying techniques and topics of other successful writers rather than building students' writing skills themselves.
Yes, it's a great course for anyone remotely interested in public writing.
